The comparison samples include four temporal nodes: 2000, 2005, 2010, and 2020, given that SPAM is available in these years.Full size imageLimitations and prospectsThe dataset developed in this study shows high accuracy in spatial allocation for domain food crops. However, its accuracy is comparatively lower for certain industrial and economic crops. This inconsistency is primarily due to the coarse resolution (10 km) of the GAEZ crop natural growth suitability data, which is not consistent with the high-resolution (30 m) input land use datasets. The resolution mismatch causes significant uncertainty in the spatial allocation of crops40. As the GAEZ dataset is designed for global agricultural assessments49, it may underestimate crop plant suitability in some regions, potentially causing uncertainty in crop mapping. Furthermore, the accuracy is also limited by the lack of complete prefecture-level statistical data. For instance, linear interpolation was used to estimate missing values in prefecture-level statistics, which oversimplified the variation trends in the harvest area22,68. Moreover, there is inherent uncertainty in the county-level statistical validation data27.Therefore, the spatial distribution of crop plant suitability is the foundation for accurate crop spatial downscaling. Future research should focus on improving methods for assessing the plant suitability and potential yield of crops under changing climatic and anthropogenic conditions69,70. For instance, integrating the crop plant suitability assessment framework AEZ (Agro-Ecological Zoning) into the crop spatial allocation model could help improve the simulation accuracy71,72. Moreover, machine learning technologies provide a promising approach for assessing crop plant suitability. For example, the maximum entropy model has proven effective in evaluating the plant suitability of crops such as rice, wheat, and soybean39,69,73. Furthermore, incorporating deep learning-based crop recognition through satellite imagery into the data fusion framework will enhance the accuracy of the allocated maps and provide more detailed and reliable data support for agricultural monitoring and analysis74. Moreover, the advent of large language models introduces robust tools capable of extracting valuable agricultural insights from vast collections of historical and contemporary inventories75. Leveraging these tools will significantly advance the construction of multi-scale and long-term agricultural statistical databases (covering crop yields, fertilizer use, field management, etc.)76. This progress will facilitate data downscaling at finer statistical units, expand the variables of the crop maps, and promote their application in climate change adaptation and sustainable agricultural development.Usage NotesThis study integrated multiscale agricultural statistical data and multisource spatial datasets to map the harvest area of 16 crops in China at a 1-km resolution from 1990 to 2020 with 5-year intervals. The prefecture-level crop statistics were downscaled to grids based on the integration of natural and economic factors affecting agricultural practices. The built dataset addresses the data gap in spatially explicit maps for multiple crops over a long time span in China. It can offer valuable insights for analyzing changes in China’s crop cultivation patterns and their impacts on environmental pollution and ecosystem services. Additionally, the dataset could be used as crucial inputs for land-surface ecosystem models (e.g., Lund-Potsdam-Jena managed Land model) and integrated assessment models (e.g., Global Change Analysis Model). Since the dataset aligns well with national, provincial, and prefectural statistics, it may help support further analysis in socioeconomic research.In future research, a key challenge is to assess crop plant suitability scores at a high spatial resolution to improve the accuracy of crop mapping. Moreover, it is also crucial to integrate crop-specific maps derived from remote sensing products into the crop statistical data allocation framework. To further improve the usability and accuracy of these datasets, it is essential to collect statistical data over longer periods with continuous, complete time series and at finer spatial resolutions. With these potential improvements in the future, this dataset will become a dynamic and open-source program that can be continually updated to reflect changing crop patterns. This ongoing development will provide a solid foundation for future applications in agricultural modelling and land use management.

Distinguishing the flow of airborne microorganisms along with environmental conditions and their influence on historic heritage buildings
                    L. de-Lemos-Medina 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3795-73541,2, A. Bermúdez-Marín3, D. Jaikel-Víquez 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3553-53934,5,6, N. Camacho-Cambronero4, A. Segura-Vargas4, A. Gómez-Arrieta4, Y. Mora-Quirós5, K. Ureña-Alvarado7, L. Rautenberg8, I. Fonseca-Alfaro9,10, P. Calderón-Mesén5,11, M. Sandoval-Gutiérrez12, M. Redondo-Solano4,6,13 & …O. A. Herrera-Sancho 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8871-171X5,9,10,14 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 28750 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Air microbiologyCharacterization and analytical techniquesEnvironmental healthEnvironmental impactEnvironmental monitoring

AbstractThe National Theater of Costa Rica is a national symbol of our country and an important architectural landmark. It was built in 1897 and is decorated with large-format paintings made by Italian artists. One of these painters was Paolo Serra, who was in charge of decorating three chambers, including the Management’s Office (MO). A yearly volumetric air sampling was conducted in seven rooms of the theater, showing high levels of circulating fungal spores in the MO. Thus, further analysis was carried out in this venue. First, the environmental conditions (wind velocity, temperature, relative humidity, and particles) were monitored. Then, the air and particles’ flow and the probability of particles concentration were simulated for different scenarios of natural ventilation using a Discrete Phase Model. This allowed us to identify areas where damage and microorganisms were probably more prevalent. The artworks in this chamber were analyzed to determine the types of damages identified: buckling, cracks, cuts, craquelure, holes, scratches, color gaps with exposed fabric or wall, insect debris, flaking, humidity stains, interventions of old restorations, opaque stains, whitish stains and total loss of the original image. As a complement, a microbiological sample was held in 34 sites of interest, resulting in the isolation and identification of five bacterial isolates and thirteen fungi. We identified the artist’s main colour palette: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine and natural barite. We can conclude that artworks under non-controlled environmental conditions may present a significant degree of deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration.

                        IntroductionCultural historical buildings represent a form of expression which frames certain feelings and describes the social and economical state of societies within a given moment. It is necessary to preserve these constructions for the next generation because of their great historical value, which allows us to understand various aspects of societies, such as their history and development. These cultural heritage conservation processes are supported by a series of problem-solving perspectives and tools that allow the identification of materials and considerations from the point of view of technique and technology used by artists for their intentions and creative process1,2,3,4,5. Little is known about the environmental impact of geographical location on heritage buildings, especially of those located in tropical countries, along with the intention of its construction and it is not clear what factors represent a key challenge to ensure the conservation of the artworks in these atmospheres.Therefore, this pilot study seeks to remedy these challenges by analyzing the environmental conditions of the Management’s Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR [built in 1891-1897]) and to determine their impact on the large-format paintings located within this chamber (see Fig. 1 for our artistic visualization). The NTCR is a historical building that represents society’s desire to experience various expressions of art locally, like other theaters’ intent throughout Europe and Latin America6. In this building, the south and east sides are lined with typically busy streets (pedestrians and vehicles), while the north and west sides have a plaza where many pigeons live and where people pass through all day long. The MO is located in the southwest corner of the building (Fig. 2) and is decorated with wall-to-wall murals and a large-format oil painting on the ceiling, all painted by Italian artist Paolo Serra. Environmental conditions play an important role in the maintenance of these historic buildings, especially those that shelter important artworks that are exposed to climate changes and different conditions since the time of its construction7,8. Therefore, environmental conditions could be a major factor, causing degradation damage to historic heritage if there are no climatized systems that keep the temperature and relative humidity under control, independently of the external conditions. Another important practical implication is that when the historic buildings are open to the public, there are greater probabilities that the temperature, humidity, airborne microorganisms, internal microclimate, and the energy performance of the entire system will vary8.To a limited extent, three methods have been identified as being potentially important for keeping the internal environmental conditions of historic buildings under control: (1) natural ventilation, (2) forced ventilation and (3) air conditioning. Most historic buildings were designed and built using natural ventilation (1), accordingly, it is an additional challenge to make modifications that allow the inclusion of any of the other types of techniques, namely (2) and (3), especially in those that contain cultural heritage without causing structural harm or several major drawbacks to the artworks9. It has been shown that there is an unambiguous relationship between temperature variations and paintings, specifically thermal fatigue could be generated, which has possible connections to the artworks’ damages10. It is worth mentioning that the NTCR only has an air conditioning system in the main chamber, yet the rest of the rooms do not have controlled environmental conditions. The MO chamber has three large windows that are periodically opened. The artworks are not exposed to the public, except for special visitors with controlled access, including diplomats, researchers, conservators, restorers, and visitors by appointment or formal invitation. The access door to this room is located on the north side, next to the main entrance of the building. Once inside, one can appreciate the large format paintings that delicately decorate all the walls and ceiling of the chamber. The study’s objective was to examine these large-format paintings exhibited under non-controlled environmental conditions from an interdisciplinary viewpoint for evidence findings that methodically assess the conservation state, i.e. the deterioration and biodeterioration, chromatic alteration, and the artist’s color palette (Fig. 1). Finally, our aim is therefore to provide a systematic correlation between these parameters and deterioration that can be identified in the artworks. It is worth mentioning that in previous works at the NTCR, we observed a new fungal species associated with damaging cultural heritage11: we distinguished particular fluorescent areas which were recognized through its red-coral fluorescence as Madder Lake12, we identified Carlo Ferrario’s main colour palette, along with we successfully achieved the characterization of eight genera of calcareous nannofossils found in the ground layers of his artwork13. Carlo Ferrario was an Italian artist, who was commissioned to paint Musas I and Musas II, two of the most important and representative paintings of the NTCR. However, our goal of having a deeper understanding of the inexorable complexity which surrounds the artwork’s habitat, colour modification suitable to environmental adaptation, and the pictorial materials used by artists from respective epochs to devise a historic building that has remained elusive.Fig. 1Multidisciplinary approach to the study of the effect of environmental conditions on the artworks found in the Management’s Office of the National Theater of Costa Rica. This study aims to describe how temperature, relative humidity, air flow and microbial colonization have deteriorated the murals, and the ceiling painted by the Italian artist Paolo Serra. The room is decorated with Pompeian inspired art and is located at the entrance of the theater, in the southwest corner. As shown in the illustration, it has three windows facing the outside environment where air, light and diverse microorganisms can enter the venue. Evelyn María Zamora Conejo partially created the figure. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imageFig. 2Location of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR). (A) The MO is located in the southwest corner of the NTCR, bordered to the south by one of the Capitals’ main streets, and a plaza, filled with pigeons and pedestrians, to the west. (B) The room has three windows that are usually open throughout the week and a door that leads to the theater’s entrance hallway. As shown in the panel (C), the room is completely decorated with paintings by Italian artist Paolo Serra, in a clear Pompeian style. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imagePaolo SerraPaolo Serra was an Italian painter trained at the academies of Naples and Florence. Later, he worked as a teacher at the Academy of Rome. After that, he traveled to Costa Rica to fulfill a contract that entrusted him with painting part of the decorative artworks of the NTCR. Upon completing these paintings, he settled permanently in the country where he carried out other commissions, such as the paintings for the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Heredia, the old Casa Cural of the Villa de Barva in Heredia, and the Chapel of the Hospicio Carlos María Ulloa. Unfortunately, out of these three places, only the painting of Hospicio has survived14,15.Serra’s style was distinguished by its dynamism, intense chromaticism, and a clear influence by Pompeian murals. He used to decorate his paintings with decorative borders, frequently using repeated motifs that he may have executed using molds. There are variations in the painter’s signatures: in some of the works at the NTCR, he signed as Paolo, while in others he used the name Pablo. This could be due to an adaptation to the Latin American context of the time or, perhaps, to the fact that one of his assistants signed on his behalf, a common practice at that time. For this research, two types of artworks were analyzed: oil on canvas attached to the ceiling and a mural on the west elevation composed of four paintings to complete the chamber known as MO. Both artworks were produced in 1897 by Paolo Serra (1860-1900), as part of the construction of the NTCR. In addition to the mural paintings at the NTCR, a few easel works are known, such as landscapes, still life, and portraits, which are currently part of private collections. Paolo Serra died on December 9, 1900, in the city of Heredia at the age of 40.Results and discussionIdentification of deteriorations in the artworks under studyPhotographs in the visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) spectrum were generated for each of the paintings studied. Examples of these pictures are presented in Figs. 2B, 5, and 6. Based on the analysis of the photographs and ocular inspection carried out in situ at the NTCR, several damages and significant deterioration were identified. As a guide to determine the type of damage the following bibliography was consulted: Australian Institute for the Conservation of Cultural Material Inc (AICCM)16, Mayorga17 and Calvo18. Supplementary Table 2 shows the definition and general characterization of these deteriorations found and Table 1 presents the identification number, name and percentage of damage, and the quadrants in which each is presented in the painting of the MO ceiling. For example, cracks were identified in all the quadrants. The damages are also illustrated with an image of the actual damage found in each of the artworks in question and their location according to the previously established grid. Fig. 5B illustrates the damages found in the painting of the ceiling. It is worth mentioning that, as an example of the identification of the damages, a zoom of the grid number 28 is presented, which has many damages identified by different colors: cracking, cracks, excrement of insects, opaque spots, exposed support, holes, and scratches.Table 1 Table of damages by quadrant on Management Office ceiling (Danthe y Rafael).Full size tableAerial microorganisms contamination of the NTCRThe fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the NTCR (i.e. Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men’s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, MO, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Theater Box, see Supplementary Figure S1) was determined throughout the year 2022. As described in the Methods section, one monthly sampling was carried out, except for June and December for reasons beyond the control of the study. In June, Hurricane Bonnie prevented visitors from entering the facility, and in December the NTCR was closed for the holiday season. Therefore, the results reflect data collected during the ten months of the year under study.Table 2 shows the fungal aerial concentration by cubic meter of the seven rooms sampled. The highest mean concentration was found in the Hall attached to the Ladies’ Cafeteria (1355 ± 459 spores/m³) and the lowest in the Smoking Lounge for Ladies (701 ± 275 spores/m³). However, the NTCR MO presented the highest concentration of all the samplings during April (4408 spores/m³). This was the month that presented the highest mean fungal concentration (1610 ± 1368 spores/m³), while July was the lowest (548 ± 174 spores/m³). Significant statistical differences were found between the fungal aerial concentration of each month (F = 2.264; df = 9; p = 0.03). The data was divided into three groups: the first group included the months of March and July, the second group January, February, May, August, September, October, and November; and only April in the third group. This indicates that the months with lower concentrations (March and July) presented significant differences respect to the other months of the year, which in turn, showed significant differences compared to April, the month with the highest concentration. It is worth noting that the high fungal concentrations found in April are due to the levels found in the NTCR’s MO. In Fig. 3A, the boxplot graphic of the monthly measurements of the fungal aerial concentration of all the rooms sampled is presented and includes specifically the value of Cladosporium spp. fungal spore concentration since this is presented in the biggest amount, so that is the most representative. It is worth mentioning that similar results have been documented for other indoor environments in Costa Rica. In a study conducted inside three schools located in the Province of Heredia, high fungal aerial concentrations were reported during the months of May and October (rainy season, ranging from 3194 to 3747 spores/m³) and the lowest on March (1392 ± 120 spores/m³). Once again, the main fungal spore identified belonged to the genus Cladosporium19. On the other hand, a study analyzing the fungal aerial concentration of the outside environment of an academic institution found much lower concentrations with a yearly mean of 444 ± 202 spores/m³. Eighteen types of spores were identified, the majority of which were sexual spores20. These results exemplify the importance of ventilation of enclosed spaces, since a lack of ventilation could result in a concentration of spores.Table 2 Fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the Costa Rican National Theater (TNCR), during 2022.Full size tableFig. 3Aerial microbiological contamination of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR).  (A) Graphic shows in light blue, the quartiles of the monthly aerial microbiological spore concentration of seven chambers within the NTCR that was determined throughout the year 2022, being Cladosporium’s spores, represented by the red square dot the most frequently found in the theater’s air. During October 2023, further analyses were carried out in the MO (B), involving active and passive aerial studies. Seventeen sampling sites were chosen including measurements at ground level and different heights (1.3 m and 2.6 m from the floor). Colour scales are used to represent the distribution of microbial contamination found. (C) Cladosporium’s spores were the most frequently found. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imageThe high concentration of fungal spores per cubic meter found during 2022 in the MO is a matter of concern, given that it is a space actively used by different NTCR’s personnel who are thus, being exposed to fungal antigens and spores for prolonged periods of time. This is relevant because there is a correlation between high spore concentrations and occupational risk in asthmatic workers and those allergic to Penicillium and/or Alternaria alternata21. It is worth noting that Penicillium is one of the main genera of fungi found throughout the NTCR’s air and walls22. Additionally, the entire enclosure in which Serra’s artworks are located could be bio deteriorated by these fungi. The latter happens because paintings are made of different materials composed of organic and inorganic molecules, which under the right environmental conditions, can lead to the colonization of a wide variety of microorganisms that cause both aesthetic and structural deterioration23. Therefore, additional experiments were carried out to evaluate the fungal and bacterial contamination of this chamber. Seventeen sampling sites were selected for passive and active air samplings (see Fig. 3B) and 34 for microbiological isolation (ten from the murals and 24 from the ceiling) (see Fig. 5B).Aerial contamination of the MODue to the high fungal aerial concentration found in the MO during the 2022 campaign, additional experiments were carried out to evaluate the fungal and bacterial contamination of this chamber (refer to Methods section Microbial Contamination of the MO). Seventeen sampling sites were selected for passive and active air monitoring in this room (see Fig. 3B). The results of these sampling are presented in Table 3.Table 3 Passive and active air sampling of the Management’s Office.Full size tableAs seen in Table 3, the north side and southeast corner were the places within the MO with the highest concentrations of both fungi and bacteria. There are two factors that can explain the high concentration of microorganisms in these areas. Firstly, this chamber has a window facing one of the busiest streets in terms of traffic and pedestrians in the province of San José (“Avenida Segunda”, in Spanish) and another one facing the Culture Place (“Plaza de la Cultura”, in Spanish). Thus, the highest concentration of microorganisms was found close to these windows, coinciding with the way the air circulates inside the chamber. It is worth noting that a correlation between exposure to environmental pollution with increase in spore concentration has been documented; also, temperature increases during the dry season relate to increasing human activities that cause pollution24. This could explain the fact that April was the month with the highest concentration, as it coincides with the dry season in Costa Rica. Another finding that supports this hypothesis is the high concentration of ascospores and basidiospores (Supplementary Table 1). These fungi have been described as the dominant biological particles in aerobiological studies of tropical areas, which are dispersed through the air and whose dispersion is dependent on humidity25. Basidiomycetes, for example, are part of various organic cycles degrading substrates such as cellulose and lignin, which are also components of different artistic works. Additionally, Trichaptum abietinum has been described to produce laccase and peroxidase activity, which can decolorate different aromatic dyes used in a wide spectrum of artistic productions26.Furthermore, the second factor that affects the spore aerial concentration is the colonization of walls and ceilings a matter that is being discussed in the following section.Isolation of microorganisms from the murals and ceiling of the MO34 regions of interest (ten from the murals and 24 from the ceiling [see Supplementary Figure 2]), for possible microbial growth, were identified after the analysis of the paintings’ deterioration maps. Six out of the ten sampling sites selected on the murals were positive for microbial growth. Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Cladosporium cladosporioides complex, Yarrowia lipolytica (Candida lipolytica) and a hyaline non-identified fungal isolate were retrieved from the east side of the north wall from a crack with loss of support. Penicillium citrinum and a hyaline non-identified fungi were retrieved from another crack with loss of support from the north side of the west wall. C. cladosporioides and Bacillus cereus were retrieved from opaque stains found in the center and south side of the west wall and Sphingomonas paucimobillis was isolated from the west side of the south wall from an area with discoloration. They were retrieved from cracks and dark stains. The isolation of microbial agents shows a direct colonization of the surfaces that contributes significantly to the airborne concentration of spores, since the positive sampling areas correspond with the highest aerial concentration of microorganisms. This colonization has also been found in other paintings of the NTCR like Carlo Ferrario’s Musas I and II where Penicillium, Cladosporium and Bacillus were the main agents of biodeterioration identified22.Cladosporium spp. (the most frequently isolated fungi within the NTCR) is also the main biological agent described in biodeterioration processes in wall paintings27. This agent was found in several sampling sites in the MO and in the passive and active aerial studies. The deterioration mechanism described by Savkovic28 and collaborators indicates that the fungus can cause surface deterioration, causing brown discoloration stains, or even deep penetrating the artwork, surpassing the layer of paint and reaching the support. This is achieved through mechanical activities, such as the penetration of hyphae that increases the internal pressure of the painting leading to the formation of cracks. In addition, it causes damage through the chemical activity of extracellular enzymes secreted by the fungus when trying to use paint components as a source of nutrients. A study conducted in Brazil found that spores of Cladosporium cladosporioides and C. spinulosum are also capable of secreting enzymes for cellulose metabolism, which is a finding of special importance for museums with artworks made of wood29.Fungi of the genus Penicillium sp. have also been described in the literature as fungal agents of biodeterioration. It has been shown that Penicillium spores are capable of surviving in indoor environments for long periods of time, in addition to being dry-walled spores, which makes them light and easily dissociable from their reproductive structures30. These characteristics make the spores of this microorganism easily airborne and ideal for colonization of internal spaces such as the NTCR MO. Regarding relevant enzymes in the process of wear and tear of artistic artworks, different enzymes with proteolytic and cellulolytic activity, such as caseases and cellulases, have been found in vitro studies28. These enzymes can degrade numerous common substrates used in the production of artistic artworks, such as silk, wool, adhesives of layers of paint, paper, among others. Savkovic and collaborators also found that several species of Penicillium can excrete exopigments of different colors depending on the environmental conditions in which the fungus is found, which also contributes to the aesthetic degradation of artworks. One of the conditions that can favor the formation of these pigments is the availability of carbon, which could be found in high concentrations in this NTCR enclosure due to the external contamination to which it is exposed that was mentioned above.As for the bacteria, the highest number of isolates obtained from both the walls and the ceiling, were of the genus Staphylococcus. The members of the genus Staphylococcus are Gram-positive cocci that produce biofilms (polysaccharide matrixes) which allow them to adhere to many different surfaces31, in this case paintings. S. paucimobilis is a Gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium found in soil, aquatic and hospital environments. It produces a yellow pigment and is mobile through flagelli32. Finally, B. cereus is a Gram-positive rod also commonly found in soil and food. It is worth mentioning that it produces spores that are resistant to adverse environmental conditions, such as extreme temperatures, different pHs and low humidity33. This adaptation has allowed it to be a bacterium usually found colonizing the paintings of the NTCR22. The last column includes the main elements for every type of pigment.Full size tableConclusionsThese research aimed to examine for the first time Serra’s paintings under non-controlled environmental conditions in a historic heritage building. It methodically assesses the deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration, along with the artist’s color palette. One of the most significant outcomes of this cutting-edge multidisciplinary research, assembled by our fluid simulation using solid particle dynamics in the environment chamber along with experimental data of wind speed, temperature, and particle size, among others, was the recognition of specific zones, at the artworks, which could be affected by their visual appearance over the time since the painting’s creation. The second major finding to emerge was that following the regions of interest previously obtained, we identified a considerable amount of deterioration patterns, biodeterioration microorganisms, and degradation of colour in the paintings. This finding has important suggestions for establishing affordable, compact, efficient, accessible, and novel non-destructive techniques, especially in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America in historic heritage buildings. The third significant finding of this investigation was that in an exploratory experiment we recognized the main artist’s colour palette, which includes: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine, and natural barite. There is abundant room for further progress in determining the stratigraphic’s internal nature of the degradation of colour discovered in the outer green layers of the painting.MethodsPiece of study and characteristicsThe artwork of the ceiling (Danthe and Raphael) in the MO of the NTCR is made with the marouflage technique, which consists of adhering manufactured artworks on a flexible support to a more rigid support. The east wall and the ceiling were considered as a particle trap to determine the number of particles trapped from the surrounding pollution.The model used for the analysis is a dense discrete particle model (DDPM) to incorporate the wind flow and the particle flow entering the room. The particles flow and the wind flow are inserted in the normal direction to the entrance of the windows at an average temperature of \(25\,^{\circ }\)C, a dispersion parameter of 4, a rosin-rammler distribution for the minimum diameter of 1 \(\mu\)m, an average diameter of 4.8 \(\mu\)m obtained from the room measurements and a maximum diameter of 10 \(\mu\)m. The mass flow is dependent on the velocity so for each case the mass flow is calculated keeping the cross-sectional area and the particle concentration constant. The simulation configuration will be with a stationary phase model, the standard K-\(\epsilon\) viscosity model, gravity, and the energy equation are included. In this measuring instrument, colors are represented using coordinates in a uniform color space consisting of variable luminosity \(L^{*}\) and chromaticity indices \(a^{*}\) and \(b^{*}\). For this case, \(L^{*}\) indicates the scale from black to white, a negative value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color green, a positive value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color red, a negative value of the parameter \(b^{*}\) corresponds to blue and a positive value of \(b^{*}\) indicates closer to color yellow. The measurement of \(L^{*}\) (around 4-6 experimental points per zone) was carried out in all the regions previously established as areas of interest due to the high probability that particles would settle there, based on the simulation carried out with the ANSYS computer tool. As a consequence, it would be expected that, in the northern region of this painting, the variation of the \(L^{*}\) parameter would decrease since a lower value of \(L^{*}\) means a darker luminosity. Thus, \(L^{*}\) has been plotted as a function of the position on the grid of the painting (regions close to the frame), where the number 1 corresponds to the region closest to the windows, i.e. the western region of the NTCR, and 6 corresponds to the region closest to the west wall. Initially, they were examined using a stereoscope for macro photography. For microanalysis, each sample was mounted on a metal base and secured with double-sided carbon tape. Subsequently, the fragments were analyzed in a JEOL JSM-IT 500 scanning electron microscope under variable pressure, utilizing backscattered electron imaging to assess their structural characteristics.
